Layouts & Positioning

Inline Block

There are 4 main display properties: 

| block  | Each element sits one-on-top of the other and takes up the full width of it’s container by default. 

Accepts all css properties. | Default value for most elements, including headings, paragraphs and container elements (sections, divs, etc.) | | inline | Inline elements only take up as much space as the content itself, and flow next to each other like text. 

Inline elements won’t accept vertical padding and margin, or height and width values.  | Default value for spans, links, and images. | | inline-block | Behaves like inline elements, except that it will accept vertical padding and margin and height and width.  | Used for buttons, navigation links and simple image galleries.  | | none | Hidden from the page.  | Used to hide elements.  | | Display:  | Description | Used for | | — | — | — |

We predominately use inline-block when we want elements to sit side-by-side or only take up the natural space of the element (like buttons), but still want to be able to use other css properties like vertical padding and margin. 

.button {
  display: inline-block;
  padding: 0.5rem 2rem;
  margin: 0.5rem 0;
}

Another use-case for inline-block is to create simple image galleries. We could create a gallery using flexbox / gridlex, but the advantage of inline-block in this circumstance is that within the content management system it’s easier for a non-technical client to add a class to an element itself rather than needing to add a parent container with a class of grid as well as a class on the element itself. 

.one-third {
  display: inline-block;
  margin: 1%;
  width: 31%;
}
.two-thirds {
  display: inline-block;
  margin: 1%;
  width: 64%;
}
.one-half {
  display: inline-block;
  margin: 1%;
  width: 48%;
}

Make sure that when setting the width you calculate the width + margin. 

Using cloudcannon we can set these classes in our editor.css and then are able to use them in content blocks like blog posts or text sections.
